intro: Cyanus vulgaris, commonly known as the cornflower, is a flowering plant native to Europe, western Asia, and North Africa. It is characterized by its bright blue to purple flower heads, which are composed of numerous small, radial petals. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and prefers well-drained soils in full sun. Its flowers bloom from late spring to early autumn, and the plant is often used in gardens for its ornamental value. Cyanus vulgaris is also known for its medicinal properties, having been used historically in herbal remedies.
